It was to integrate knowledge from various sources like different Cat Software, ERP, databases, information about patterns and other by means of a layer of semantic annotations, so that an engineer will have to deal just with one tool, one representation for different searches.
For example, if he wants to search for some past designs containing special features or some past designs.
We had some particular problems he would have to deal only with just one interface instead of going into various different tools, opening different files and checking by quite a lengthy process.

So from this we hadn't had an idea that if the system has described all the algorithms in terms of their inputs and outputs, it can plan itself some complex workflows in it can produce chains or directed acyclic graphs of these algorithms.
For example, if we want to generate the decision tree from a relational data set through propositional isation.

Basically the two main queries would be give me a program that takes a classified relational data set represented as Prolog facts and produces an IRF file that this in case we have just the decision tree algorithms for workout which take a RF files.
And then the second query would be give me.
A program that takes an RF file and produces a decision tree.
So once we came up with the idea that we could actually generate the workflows, we thought about it.
Well, whether we want to pursue this idea or not, and it seemed that it would be interesting from two points of view, once for the user.
Actually the data mining process, handling relational data and the background knowledge is quite complex, so we want to hide.

As much as it from the user, as is possible and this workflow idea would allow us to do this without having to wrap basically the whole process or one combination of the algorithms as one process, so it's on one head, it gives us the flexibility to exchange different parts of the process as we develop new ones, or as is more suitable for a particular problem.
And at the same time height as much of it from the user as possible, so that for the user it's just the whole workflow is a black box.
He just describes the initial output and initial input and the final output.
And also from the point of view of a developer or data miner.
It's interesting because we have somewhere stored the information about the whole process, so it enables us to repeat the experiments quite easily.
Even experiments we have no designed ourselves.
And in individual components are often developed by different people, and so we can focus on experimenting just with parameters of some components and view other as black box.

So we don't have to necessarily understand everything and also all the components are described in a uniform way, so it's easy for us relatively to understand or not to understand in depth, but to have an idea about.
An algorithm can do what are the typical parameters and what inputs and outputs are required.
